item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: JPigford
item.description: Is there a program that will convert line endings to a certain format no matter what OS you are using? I am thorougly confused at why only this file is doing the Mac line endings...

item.title: Ticket #1062 (Categories display items from subcategories but don't count them) updated
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1062 (Categories display items from subcategories but don't count them) created
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description:
wp_list_cats('sort_column=name&optioncount=1')

That currently returns the list of categories hierarchically and counts the entries in each category. If you have an entry tagged with a subcategory and not the parent, the parent category correctly displays subcategory items. However, it doesn't "count" the items that belong to a subcategory and not the parent.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description:
I use Visual Slickedit which has a view that shows the file in hex. If you have shell access you can use the od -x command to dump the file in hex and look. 0x0d is a Mac ending, 0x0a is a Unix ending, 0x0d0a is a Windows ending.

edited on: 03-08-05 19:34

item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description: That CSS file has Macintosh line endings, being a single '\r' at the end of each line. It was saved by a Mac text editor in Mac format and uploaded or copied in verbatum. Perhaps the other ones weren't, but the one you linked to is.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: JPigford
item.description: But what confuses me is that I've edit *countless* CSS files, PHP files, etc etc for use with WP over the past 6 months and never had this issue. It's only happening with this particular CSS file. If I edit other CSS files for other themes, they are fine. Not sure if it's something *in* the CSS file or a way it was saved possibly?

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description: file() is a convenience function. It just happens to have problems deciphering Macintosh line endings without that particular option turned on. Therefore, to make it so that WordPress isn't reliant on a server-side configuration option it means constructing a replacement function -- that would operate precisely the same as file() _with_ the configuration option turned on -- or, essentially, reinventing the wheel to get around a PHP installation weakness.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: JPigford
item.description:
Both servers with the issue are running 4.3.10

So everything could more or less function the same without using the file()? If so, what's the real point of it?

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description:
What version of PHP is this, by the way?

<a href="​http://www.zend.com/manual/function.file.php">Here</a> is a link showing the function used and mentioning the use of the line ending auto detect configuration. That said, as Matt also said, it could always be worked around by not using the file() function to read in that file and normalize to a certain line-ending format, obviating the need for the file() function and the subsequent configuration option.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: JPigford
item.description: I'm not mad. I'm just stating the facts. And I wsn't saying you were affiliated with WordPress by suggesting I edit the php.ini file...I was just saying that if that's what was required to make WP work on people's servers then WP should try to fix the issue, not people who want to use their stuff. Thanks for your help so far, I'm just a bit frustrated that I'll have to ditch WP.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated

You hadn't heard anything, I was giving you something to try. Sorry you're not happy with my suggestion.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: JPigford
item.description:
2 things:

1) It's a problem on 2 different servers. 1 of whom's php.ini I can't edit because it's a clients and they're on a shared server.

2) This is the only time I've ever edit this issue with a CSS file in WP and I've been using my Mac with WP for 6+ months.

I don't know that's its just "a configuration" problem and if it is and it just "happened" to be the same wrong configuration on 2 totally seperate servers then it seems like it's an issue WordPress might should address instead of telling people they have to edit their php.ini file to use their software.

item.title: Ticket #1020 (Presentation area shows raw CSS instead of Theme/Author names) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description: I cannot see how it would adversely affect other sites. The simple fact is that your PHP installation is not being allowed to handle Macintosh-style line ending appropriately. It isn't a WordPress problem, it's a configuration problem. WordPress is using a built-in PHP function to read a file and that built-in function is not able to parse the file correctly because it can't auto-detect line-endings. So this will currently be a problem on any file on any site on that server that happens to have Mac line-endings and that uses a built-in PHP function to read that file in.

item.title: Ticket #1059 (Make human_time_diff() be temporally insensitive) updated
item.dc:creator: EricMeyer
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1059 (Make human_time_diff() be temporally insensitive) created
item.dc:creator: EricMeyer
item.description: Currently, human_time_diff() only works for future dates. A simple change to a single line makes it work into the past as well. Note that the routine will still only return a human-friendly time value no matter whether the interval describes the past or the future.

item.title: Ticket #966 (Previous/next page breaks when asked for displaying n days worth of posts) updated
item.dc:creator: excalin
item.description:
The right way to count the number of pages in "days" mode is to agregate similar post days together. An SQL instruction such as "DISTINCT DATE_FORMAT(post_date, \'%d %m %Y\')" in posts_nav_link works.

Unfortunately you still have to strip constraints about the postdates created by get_posts in "days" mode. To solve this I'm using an ugly, hackish solution. I put the constraints between comments in the SQL request, and I remove everything between the comments in the counting function. I hope you will find something cleaner.

item.title: Ticket #1058 (post_custom() missing globals) updated
item.dc:creator: kellan
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1058 (post_custom() missing globals) created
item.dc:creator: kellan
item.description:
the function post_custom() in template-functions-post.php doesn't work because it doesn't have access to the globals $id, or $post_meta_cache.

Patch attached.

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: I found out some more information with this bug. It seems that using the hidden values only work 50% of the time. The hidden values rely on <?php echo $comment_author_email; ?> and other tags. What happens is the tag doesn't pass anything sometimes. This will leave the email field blank, causing the error I am experiencing. If you have previously left a comment a cookie will remember your email setting, so that's my guess on why it's working for some people. Try clearing your cookies and then log in to WP and try and comment.

item.title: Ticket #1057 (Comment whitelisting before moderation) updated

item.title: Ticket #1057 (Comment whitelisting before moderation) created

I'm attaching a patch that implements the alphabetical sorting.

item.title: Ticket #1053 (Slashes added to double-quotes in < pre > found in post content) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #1053 (Slashes added to double-quotes in < pre > found in post content) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #1053 (Slashes added to double-quotes in < pre > found in post content) updated
item.dc:creator: dsandler
item.description: Eww---I didn't expect Mantis to emit the HTML un-escaped in bug lists and whatnot. Someone with Super Cool Privileges will probably have to clean up the bug report. Sorry!

item.title: Ticket #1053 (Slashes added to double-quotes in < pre > found in post content) updated
item.dc:creator: dsandler
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1053 (Slashes added to double-quotes in < pre > found in post content) created
item.dc:creator: dsandler
item.description:
Example post body (as entered in the admin pages, and verified by dumping the table in mysql):

<pre>'Singles' "Doubles"</pre>

As rendered on page (either in edit preview or on site itself):

<pre>'Singles' \"Doubles\"</pre>

Adding a call to stripslashes() to something like clean_pre() is the Wrong Thing To Do because it'll kill backslashes the user intended to be there.

A quick fix seems to involve adding a specific regexp for this case to clean_pre():

52a53

$text = str_replace('
"', '"', $text);

This seems to work for me, but I'm sure a more subtle fix is required to handle all cases.

item.title: Ticket #1017 (Suggestion: Patch to allow feed templates) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
I'm not sure that we should look in TEMPLATEPATH. I doubt people will want different feed templates per theme. Putting alternative feed templates in wp-content might suffice. However, in the future the feed "templates" might simply become functions that can be replaced via plugin.

BTW, in 1.5 you can load custom feed templates by writing a plugin that hooks into the 'template_redirect' action.

item.title: Ticket #1045 (Feed rewrite rules being written out for pages) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: We had several requests that pages have comments feeds with pretty links, just like posts. They do add to the clutter. Now that you fixed the feed flag problem, plugins can turn off page feeds if so desired.

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) updated
item.dc:creator: cavemonkey50
item.description:
Well, first of all no hacks are used. Second, require email setting is on, but the users have a correct email set.

I have attached two files. In comments1.php, the template code I was attempting to use is used. In comments2.php I have modified the <?php if ( $user_ID ) : ?> section to include hidden fields of the name, email, and url. Line 82 in both files is the starting point of the relating comment code.

comments2.php is currently working for me, however I'm not sure if that's how the comments.php was intended to be used. In all of the themes I was looking at there were no hidden fields in the <?php if ( $user_ID ) : ?> section of the template. I probably should mention that the template I'm using is my own custom template, but I have insure I am not missing any tags.

Again, to repeat this problem, when using comments1.php, a logged in user's comment will fail and a guest who's name, email, and url fields showing will not. comments2.php will work correctly. If you need any additional information, just let me know.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
Never mind.

Now that I found the fix, it seems that post 0000902 is the same problem and claims to be resolved. Sorry to waste your time.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description: BTW -- I am told on #WordPress that I should let you know that this applies to 1.5 stayhorn.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
I have uploaded the diff output of a patch that fixes the problem.

menu-header was being called, which used the $page_hook variable in the global space for generating the menu, which overwrote what was in there previously and is why the last item (in alpha order) was the one being called every time.

item.title: Ticket #948 (Authors without e-mail specified cannot comment) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I had a patch for this a while ago but forgot to upload it or fix upstream... (michel v)

edited on: 03-07-05 10:46

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
If you add:

echo $page_hook;

before and after the following code block around line 48ish:

if ( $page_hook ) {

if (! isset($_GETnoheader?))

require_once(ABSPATH . '/wp-admin/admin-header.php');

You get different values. Prior to including the header, the value is what it should be and after loading the header, the value becomes what it would be for the last added plugin.

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) updated
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1046 (Last loaded plugin's options pages shows on other plugin's options ...) created
item.dc:creator: EricAnderson
item.description:
Basicly, it comes down to do_action() in relation to this stack:

add_options_page() -> add_submenu_page() -> add_action()

I am still trying to determine why this happens, however I am fairly confident that it is a WordPress bug

item.title: Ticket #1045 (Feed rewrite rules being written out for pages) updated
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1045 (Feed rewrite rules being written out for pages) created
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description:
In classes.php, the function to generate the rewrite rules for the new static pages doesn't set the feed flag to false, and feed rewrite rules are being written. It's not that big a deal, except that the .htaccess file can grow by leaps and bounds.

I assume that a static page doesn't really need a feed, and have changed the code to set this flag to false.

item.title: Ticket #1044 (Parameter accidentally overwritten in code) updated
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1044 (Parameter accidentally overwritten in code) created
item.dc:creator: shelleyp
item.description:
In the classes.php file, the generate_rewrite_rules function has a parameter called $feed. Unfortunately, the first functionality in the file accidentally overwrites this, so when it's tested later in the code, the value is no longer viable.

I've patched the code in my copy of the file to the following (first few lines)--:

function generate_rewrite_rules($permalink_structure, $pageflg = true, $feedflg = true, $forcomments = false, $walk_dirs = true) {

$feedregex2 = ; foreach ($this->feeds as $feed) {

$feedregex2 .= $feed . '|';

}

And then use $feedflg later to test to see whether feed entries should be generated.

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) updated
item.dc:creator: 2fargon
item.description:
Status changed

Are you trying to modify the template, and use a hack to bypass the comment fields?

Can you please describe how to reproduce the bug, with detailed steps?

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) updated
item.dc:creator: cavemonkey50
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1043 (Logged in users can not post comments.) created
item.dc:creator: cavemonkey50
item.description: When using the <?php if ( $user_ID ) : ?> tag to bypass and hide the comment fields, logged in users lose the ability to post comments. Their comment will always fail with the error invalid email. Guests are unaffected by the bug and can comment as normal.
